title: Update rand_core, rand, rand_os.
body:
Of these only `rand_core` is included in the public API; regardless of `rand`
semver tricks, this is a breaking API change, but the major version is already
bumped to include the Serde serialization fixes for #265.

title: Fix serde data modeling.
body:
Adds length checks to the serde-bincode tests, ensuring that the serde `Serialize` and `Deserialize` implementations use fixed-length Serde tuples, rather than variable-length byte arrays.  This flaw in data modeling was pointed out by Trevor Perrin.

This is a breaking change to the serialization format.  It fixes it so that the Serde encoding can match the conventional encoding of each type of object, and so that Serde can be used with no overhead -- when using serde-bincode, the Serde encoding now matches the manual encoding.

Finally, it fills in a missing serde impl for `MontgomeryPoint`.

Closes #265, cf. https://github.com/dalek-cryptography/curve25519-dalek/issues/265#issuecomment-536132620

title: Remove build.rs constants generation.
body: This closes #217, removing `build.rs` entirely.  In the future, a different `build.rs` could be added that auto-selects a backend, but it seems like the current default-u64 setup has been working fine, so I don't think it's a problem worth fixing right now.

title: Small rust fixes
body:
Fixes:
- matches that boil down to a ? operator
- clippy lints not against the repo's style

See individual commit messages

title: Switch from `clear_on_drop` to `zeroize` (fixes #281)
body:
`zeroize` is WASM-friendly as it has no dependencies on C compilers.

Instead uses Rust's own volatile write semantics and compiler fences to ensure zeroization is not elided by the compiler.

title: README.md parallel_doc link fix
body: parallel_doc link fix

title: Fix issues found in Quarkslab audit

milestone.title: Patch Release
milestone.description: Bucket for changes and enhancements that don't change any API or config options, and can be bundled into the next patch release.

body:
A Quarkslab audit (to be published shortly) looked through the `curve25519-dalek` source code; this PR fixes the issues they identified.

The only serious one is that, although the rest of the `Scalar` API works with canonical scalars, the API has an "invariant loophole", `Scalar::from_bits`, which allows constructing non-reduced scalars for use in, e.g., X/Ed25519, which mandate the use of non-reduced scalars.  

However, although the group operations (scalar, point) were designed to operate on non-reduced scalars, this was not true of (scalar, scalar) addition and subtraction, and so it was possible to use the API to explicitly construct large, unreduced `Scalar`s via `from_bits` and then perform additions and subtractions which compute incorrect results.  This is now fixed, with tests that ensure that addition and subtraction work correctly on very large `Scalar` values.

A search of `Scalar::from_bits` of all Rust code on Github suggests that the function is mostly only used to implement X/Ed25519, which don't do those operations, so it's unlikely that this issue affects any existing code.  This issue was noticed independently by @str4d in #238.

Closes #238.

title: Fix link to AVX2 docs
body: Currently the library doesn't compile on `nightly` when the `avx2_backend` is enabled; this PR fixes it by fixing the links to the relevant docs.

title: `curve_models` Comment fix
body: The comment link (`https://doc-internal.dalek.rs/curve25519_dalek/curve_models/index.html`) for `curve_models` mismatch the actual link：`https://doc-internal.dalek.rs/curve25519_dalek/backend/serial/curve_models/index.html` .

title: Add a missing wrapping_sub in NAF computation.

milestone.title: Patch Release
milestone.description: Bucket for changes and enhancements that don't change any API or config options, and can be bundled into the next patch release.

body:
Found by @3for; this only affected width-7 NAF computations, which were never
used in the source tree (only width 5, optimal for dynamic cases, and 8, better
for static cases).

Closes #272

title: Update doc(include) paths.
body:
Since https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/60938 the path root changed and
these new paths are required to compile on nightly.

Closes #268.

title: Fix a typo in AVX2
body:
Last two (least significant) limbs should be `z8`, `z9`. These were probably
copy-paste typos.

title: Remove unneeded check for negativity in edwards point decompression
body:
The function `FieldElement::sqrt_ratio_i` always returns a positive root
by definition. Therefore the test for negativity in the edwards point
decompression function always returns false and we only need to flip its
sign if `compressed_sign_bit` is set.

title: Pippenger bugfix

milestone.title: Patch Release
milestone.description: Bucket for changes and enhancements that don't change any API or config options, and can be bundled into the next patch release.

body:
The Pippenger implementation in 1.2.0 (yanked) had a bug, diagnosed by @oleganza; at the largest problem sizes (using w=8), the signed digits fill the value range of an i8, and so doing computation on them to calculate the bucket index could hit an overflow.

The CI missed catching this because the test suite didn't check all the problem sizes, which I fixed in this PR.  Adding a check that the multiscalar functions work on manually-constructed extremal scalar values (which are allowed by the `Scalar` type for X/Ed25519 compatibility but aren't used as inputs to the multiscalar functions) revealed a bug in the NAF-using computation, which has no security content but has been present since the first version of the library (cc @isislovecruft); there's more details in the commit messages.

title: Use upstream intrinsics
body: Closes #256.  This is a work-in-progress.

title: Turn off default serde features but keep it as an optional dependency
body:
This is an updated version of #247 with a much more minimal change; it simply turns off default features for the serde dependency.  This was suggested by @tarcieri in #247.  

I had initially tried this, but the lack of no_std support in merlin made it look like it was not sufficient.  With updated merlin in place, it works perfectly in my no_std environment.

title: Quench snake case warning
body:
Non-functional change. Allow non-snake case in whole file to suppress warning in the following line.

https://github.com/dalek-cryptography/curve25519-dalek/blob/f630041af28e9a405255f98a8a93adca18e4315b/src/traits.rs#L328

title: Pippenger multiscalar multiplication algorithm
body:
Currently supported Straus algorithm does not improve performance as input size grows and saturates at ≈4x improvement over naïve multiplication. Pippenger’s algorithm takes advantage of very large amount of points (>190) by avoiding premultiplication of points and instead placing points in the buckets indexed by the multiplication factor. Then, buckets are cleverly added up to have their multipliers applied automatically. The process is repeated for each "digit" (that are 6 to 8 bits wide, depending on number of input points). As a result, the cost of multiplication grows slower than linearly with respect to the input size. For 1024 points Pippenger is >40% faster than Straus.

To make the gains more relatable:

0. Batch verification of less than 100 Schnorr signatures is unchanged — Straus is optimal.
1. Single 64-bit rangeproof check in Bulletproofs is unchanged — Straus is optimal.
2. 2x64-bit aggregated rangeproof check is **10% faster**. Example: a typical 2-output confidential transaction.
3. Ten 64-bit aggregated rangeproofs is **≈1.8-2x faster**. Example: a 10-output confidential transaction.

This patch adds:

1. An implementation of `VartimeMultiscalarMul` using Pippenger algorithm.
2. Dynamic switch based on input's `size_hint()` from Straus to Pippenger (at 190 points).
2. New `to_pippenger_radix` internal API to convert scalars into digits in radix 64, 128, or 256.

This addresses issue #130 and replaces previous PR #129.

title: Save 2.5% on variable-base scmul by squeezing some multiplications.
body:
This saves 4 point doublings by unwrapping the first loop iteration,
as well as 63 field multiplications (one per iteration) by managing
curve model choice explicitly.

Benchmark (the absolute numbers are slow, because it's on a turbo-disabled laptop, but the relative change is consistent):
```text
Constant-time variable-base scalar mul                        
                        time:   [98.208 us 98.334 us 98.473 us]
                        change: [-2.8943% -2.4276% -1.9647%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                        Performance has improved.
Found 9 outliers among 100 measurements (9.00%)
  2 (2.00%) high mild
  7 (7.00%) high severe
```

title:
Suppress a generated
which breaks KaTeX.
fix typo in torsion documentation
body:
redo of #240.

Simple documentation fix concerning the torsion subgroup `E[8]`.

title: Revert #219.
body: One fix to https://github.com/dalek-cryptography/curve25519-dalek/issues/232

title: Fix comment on Montgomery conversion.
body: Closes #213.

title: Multiscalar multiplication with precomputation.

milestone.description: Features we can add without breaking stability.

body:
Closes #125.

Adds two traits, `PrecomputedMultiscalarMul` and `VartimePrecomputedMultiscalarMul`, provides implementations for `EdwardsPoints` and `RistrettoPoint`s, and reworks the benchmarks to provide precomputation timings.

title: Check the equality of `EdwardsPoint`s in the projective coordinates

milestone.description: More features we can add without breaking stability.

body:
I stumbled on this sentence at [ristretto.group](https://ristretto.group/details/equality.html):

> Equality testing of points on the Edwards curve requires comparing to affine coordinates, which requires an expensive inversion. However, testing whether two points lie in the same coset can be done in projective coordinates, making it actually easier than equality testing in the original non-quotient group.

which led me to check the code here and notice this could be optimized. :smiley_cat:

title: Replace rand with rand_core+rand_os
body: You don't have to depend on the whole `rand`, instead `rand_core` and `rand_os` can be used.

title: Support passing both borrowed and owned Rngs

milestone.description: Features we can add without breaking stability.

body:
Rng was designed to support both &mut and owned usage like this.

It's slightly odd to do this on a method since Borrow exists for that, but this helps a lot with data types so one may as well use it.
